exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: 1. If you have already taken your full mealtime insulin 2-3hrs before exercise reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins (or as soon as possible) before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
2. You might need approx 15-30g of carbohydrate to prevent hypoglycaemia.
3. Check blood glucose before you start exercise and at the end of exercise.
4. If your blood glucose is < 7mmol/l before you start take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

5. If your blood glucose is >15mmol/l before you start check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team
1. Your blood sugar will likely rise with this extremely intense exercise, therefore you will unlikely need any carbohydrate to prevent hypoglyaemia during exercise but carry some with you
2. Check blood glucose before you start exercise and at the end of exercise.
3. If your blood glucose is <5mmol/l before you start take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

4. If your blood glucose is >15mmol/l before you start check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team

1. If you have already taken your full mealtime insulin 2-3hrs before exercise reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins (or as soon as possible) before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
2. You might need approx 15-30g every 30 mins to prevent hypoglycaemia. Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
3. Check blood glucose before you start, during exercise and at the end of exercise.
4. If your blood glucose is < 7mmol/l before you start take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

5. If your blood glucose is >15mmol/l before you start check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate and follow appropriate advice

1. If you have already taken your full mealtime insulin 2-3hrs before exercise reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins (or as soon as possible) before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
2. You might need 15-30g of carbohydrate to prevent hypoglyaemia
3. If you are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

4. If your exercise is team sports (e.g. football, rugby) remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training
5. Check blood glucose before you start and at the end of exercise
6. If your blood glucose is <7mmol/l before you start take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

7. If your blood glucose is >15mmol/l before you start check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team
1. Your blood glucose will likely rise with this extremely intense exercise therefore take your usual meal time insulin and basal insulin if your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal
2. You will unlikely need any carbohydrate to prevent hypoglyaemia during exercise but carry some with you
3. Check blood glucose before you start and at the end of exercise
4. If you are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

5. If your exercise is team sports (e.g. football, rugby) remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training
4. If your blood glucose is <5mmol/l before you start take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

5. If your blood glucose is >15mmol/l before you start check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team

1. If you have already taken your full mealtime insulin 2-3hrs before exercise reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins (or as soon as possible) before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
2. You might need approx 15-30g every 30 mins to prevent hypoglycaemia. Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
3. Check blood glucose before you start, during exercise and at the end of exercise.
4. If your blood glucose is <7mmol/l before you start take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

5. If your blood glucose is >15mmol/l before you start check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team
6. If you are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

7. If your exercise is team sports (e.g. football, rugby) remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
Anaerobic exercise is done at moderate to high intensity. Change to at least 4-6 on the intensity scale
1. As your blood sugar is likely to rise with anaerobic exercise no reduction in mealtime insulin or basal insulin is advised.
2. You may need to increase your basal rate during exercise to avoid hyperglycaemia - try increasing by 10% 30mins (or as soon as possible) before to 60mins after.
3. Check blood glucose before you start and at the end of exercise.
4. If starting blood glucose is <5mmol/l take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

5. If starting blood glucose is >15mmol/l check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team
Anaerobic exercise is done at moderate to high intensity. Change to at least 4-6 on the intensity scale
1. As your blood sugar may rise or remain stable with anaerobic exercise, therefore no reduction in mealtime insulin or basal insulin is advised initially.
2. Carry some carbohydrate with you as you may need it to prevent hypoglycaemia for longer duration anaerobic sessions
3. If your blood glucose tends to rise during exercise you may need to increase your basal rate during - try increasing by 10% 30mins (or as soon as possible) before to 60mins after.
4. Check blood glucose before you start, during exercise and at the end of exercise.
5. If starting blood glucose is <5mmol/l take 10-30g carbohydrate (amount depends on how much active insulin you have on board)

6. If starting blood glucose is >15mmol/l check for ketones. If you have ketones up to 1.4mmol/l limit to light intensity exercise for <30mins. If ketones >1.5mmol/l avoid exercise and follow glucose management as per your diabetes team
